attributes.alt: Cover for Anywhere Farm by Phyllis Root and illustrated by G. Brian Karas. The cover art shows people in a city garden hanging up a sign on the wall of a building that says Anywhere Farm.

elements.text: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Alphabet Knowledge; Phonological Awareness
Use Circle Time to talk about the alphabet letters
and rhyme, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking the guiding question,
Ask and answer questions about story elements; Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Distinguish words that sound similar but have different meanings.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Guide children as they blend onset and rime to form a familiar one syllable word and locate the picture.
How can we help plants grow?
What plants do you see in the book you are reading?
What would you use to dig little pretend holes for planting seeds?
Draw some plants. How many plants did you draw? Write that number on the picture.
What place in this room would be a good place to grow a plant?
What materials would you use to make a little plant?
. Can you write uppercase and lowercase
What could you use from this center to make a pretend plant?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about how the author asks and answers questions about plants.

Have children ask questions to help them figure out which vegetable is hidden in the bag.
How can we help plants grow?
Does the book you are reading have any plants or animals in it?
Can you show me how you could pretend to be a seed, a sprout, and a tall plant?
Collect some cubes. Pretend they are seeds. Can you tell me how many you have?
Can you make a list of things you need to plant an anywhere farm?
Can you show me the materials that you would use to make a huge plant?
. Can you point to the letter that makes the /d/ sound?
Can you use blocks to build an anywhere farm?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build Earth Science background, have children plant a seed, and introduce vocabulary
Ask and answer questions about story elements; Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Use and identify different digital tools.
Encourage children to think about the roles of buyer and seller.
Help children act as buyers and sellers.
Guide children to understanding that  money is used to buy things.
How can we help plants grow?
How does the book that you are reading right now help you think about plants?
Why would you need help if you wanted to use the Internet to learn more about vegetables?
Look at some seeds. How will they look after they grow?
How does a butterfly act when it comes to visit a vegetable farm?
How would you use construction paper to make paper vegetables?
Can you show me how you can use these materials to make rows in a vegetable garden?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about fairy tales, reality and fantasy, and introduce vocabulary

How can we help plants grow?
Ask and answer questions about story elements.

Help children use prepositions to describe the location of different pretend foods.
Encourage children to expand their understanding and use of prepositions.
How can we help plants grow?
Is the book you are listening to about things that are real or make-believe?
If you wanted to read a fairy tale on the Internet how would you ask for help from a grown-up?
Draw a beanstalk. Measure with connecting cubes. How tall is it?
Think about a funny place to plant vegetables. Where would that be?
Paint a picture of one leaf and a smaller or larger leaf.
What is the first letter in the word
Can you make two sprouts with  clay and compare them?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to engage children in reciting  garden nursery rhymes, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by asking the guiding question:
How can we help plants stay healthy?
Share and repeat the details in a text; Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s writing prompt:
Write about how to help plants grow.
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we help plants grow?
Is the book you are reading like
How it is the same or different?
Pretend you have vegetables to sell. How would you create a farmers’ market?
Use cubes to create three  plants of different sizes. Which  is the tallest? Which is the shortest?
Imagine an anywhere farm in your shoe. Would it be fun to have that?
Can you make up names for new kinds of vegetables?
Can you read an Alphabet Book with a friend?
Can you create a container that could be used to raise plants for an anywhere farm?
